WRITING.TITLE: Almost everyone is lying every time they say "just kidding"
WRITING.TEXT: I've noticed that when Americans use the exact words "just kidding", they are just trying to cover up their true feelings which were just expressed. I find that similar terms like "just joking around" or "I'm only messing with you" are more honest.

He certainly was not interested in building up our egos. It makes sense if you think of bad playing as a pig that can magically change into a swan just by... um... ok it's a bad analogy but we never question the band teacher.

WRITING.TITLE: Whether a pig walks by or runs by, it's still a pig.
WRITING.TEXT: This was the mantra of my high school band teacher. He wanted us to practice getting things right first, then speeding them up to the necessary tempo.

WRITING.TITLE: What is something everyone expects you would be good at, but in reality you aren't?

WRITING.TEXT: ENHANCE

Until I started college (at 18), I thought engineers were all people who drove trains. I literally would have chosen an engineering degree over "business" if I had understood what engineering actually was! Now that I have a degree in "business" I realize that "business" is just basic math + some common sense.

My dad was pretty high up in a large payroll processing company and told us stories of a VP babysitting his daughter's Tamagotchi during important meetings. Now we all babysit our own phones and check on them every 2 minutes just to be sure they are OK.

WRITING.TITLE: Every once in a while, good friends are having a discussion on Reddit while having no idea they know each other.

WRITING.TEXT: The Canadian PM bumped into a lady and he didn't notice, then he had to apologize to everyone about it. It was obviously an accident, but people love to read into things... https://heatst.com/politics/canadian-pm-justin-trudeau-elbows-female-politician-in-the-chest/

My job allows dogs, and we're hiring! We need some software developers, no experience required and we will train you on the job (CS degree preferred but not necessary if you have good problem solving skills). The main downside is that you have to work on "legacy systems" that aren't object-oriented and don't support any real version control. However, the pay is great and the office environment is not too bad. (Orange County, CA)

Mini-tips: 1. Use cash whenever possible (like actual dollar bills and coins). This habit will help you "feel" the money leaving your hands, and has been shown to reduce spending. Only carry enough to cover what you expect to need that day/week, with a small buffer. 2. I try to only buy things from places with good return policies, and hang on to the receipts. If something just isn't as "magical" as I expected it to be, I return it. 3. Look over ALL your accounts on a monthly basis. I use mint.com for this, and without it, I might forget that I slowly built up a small balance on my costco/AMEX card. When I see that, I go pay it off and keep it from surprising me. 4. Find free (or nearly-free) hobbies and friends to share them with. Wait for movies to go on Netflix or iTunes rental instead of seeing everything in the theaters. 5. Get practice cooking with people who cook well, like mom, and learn this valuable skill. Eating out is super expensive and should never become a habit to those wanting to keep a budget. 6. Learn a new skill that can become a new career or side income. For me, that was photography, and now has become software development. I also made sure I performed well at my day job and I saw raises as a result.

They are not actually running in the background, that's a common misconception. This explains it well: http://www.speirs.org/blog/2012/1/2/misconceptions-about-ios-multitasking.html
Glad to hear it's faster on older devices, though! I had an iPhone 3G when iOS 4 came out and it made the phone almost unusably slow. It took at least 3 months for them to come up with an update which improved it.
